entry.title: More Than Cleanliness: The Truth About OCD
entry.summary: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is often misunderstood by the general public, commonly reduced to stereotypes involving excessive hand washing or cleanliness. While these symptoms may be part of OCD, the reality of this complex mental health condition goes far beyond surface-level cleanliness. OCD is a serious and often debilitating disorder that affects millions worldwide, influencing thoughts, behaviors, and daily functioning in profound ways. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is an anxiety disorder characterized by persistent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors or mental acts (compulsions) performed to reduce the distress caused by these thoughts. These obsessions and compulsions are intrusive, time-consuming, and interfere significantly with everyday life. OC‚Ä¶

entry.title: Apache Helm Chart
entry.summary:
This Helm chart deploys an Apache HTTP Server on a Kubernetes cluster. https://raw.githubusercontent.com/helm/helm/main/scripts/get-helm-3 Package the chart: helm package . helm install apache ./apache --namespace apache-namespace --create-namespace replicaCount: 2 image: service: resources: Accessing the Deployment Check the status of your pods and services: kubectl get pods -n apache-namespace
_kubectl port-forward svc/apache 8080:80 -n apache-namespace Open your browser and visit: http://localhost:8080 helm uninstall apache -n apache-namespace **helm install apache ./apache \ Features _helm version Check Helm release status: _helm status apache -n apache-namespace Inspect pod logs: kubectl logs -n apache-namespace

entry.title: Kubernetes Ingress Controller on Minikube Cluster
entry.summary:
Steps to implement ingress: 2) Check minikube cluster status and nodes : minikube status 3) Create one yaml file for apache deployment and service : apiVersion: apps/v1 apiVersion: v1 4) Apply apache deployment : kubectl apply -f apache-deployment.yaml apiVersion: apps/v1 apiVersion: v1 kubectl apply -f nginx-deployment.yaml minikube addons enable ingress apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1 host: "tws.com" http: paths:
path: /apache pathType: Prefix backend: service: name: apache-service port: number: 80 path: /nginx pathType: Prefix backend: service: name: nginx-service port: number: 80 9) Apply the Ingress resource : kubectl apply -f ingress.yaml echo "$(minikube ip) tws.com" | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts curl http://tws.com/apache to access the Apache service. http://tws.com/apache http://tws.com/nginx to access the NGINX service. http://tws.com/nginx OR port forward to access the Apache service on browser. kubectl port-forward svc/apache-service 8081:80 --address 0.0.0.0 & port forward to access the NGINX service on browser. kubectl port-forward svc/nginx-service 8082:80 --address 0.0.0.0 &

entry.title: And so it begins
entry.summary: Content consumption is hard. With the amount of AI generated crap out there along with the dynamic and ever evolving landscape of the web; even when I try watching videos on youtube leisurely it becomes a binging session with hard disciplined study following each video. After about a year of such binge sessions and learning new technologies and stacks I realised my YouTube watch later and favourites playlists contents have become textbooks in themselves. So here I am, a fullstack web dev trying to annotate my thoughts as I go along surfing the web on my learning journey. From Java to PHP and from react to htmx I‚Äôll try to cover all kinds of content to learn and discover more and more about this strange world of web and leave no stone unturned. After 2 failed attempts at microblogging, this is gonna be a new take but with a twist. Concept - each post contains a video I‚Äôm still working on the order of videos to cover. So stay tuned. The goal is to make 2 posts a week covering 2 elaborate videos. Feel free to follow me to get updates on upcoming posts and let‚Äôs begin the Dev Bytes!

entry.title: üöÄ Getting Started with Solana: A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.summary: ‚úçÔ∏è If you're a students, builders, and blockchain beginners looking to understand Solana in plain English. Solana is one of the fastest-growing blockchain platforms in the world ‚Äî and in this article, we‚Äôll break down what it is, why it‚Äôs different, and the core concepts that make it powerful. All explained in a clear, relatable, and builder-friendly way. Solana is a high-performance blockchain designed for speed, scalability, and low transaction costs. In simple terms, it‚Äôs like a super-fast, decentralized computer that anyone can use to build apps, launch tokens, create NFTs, or transfer money ‚Äî without needing a central authority or third-party service. üß† Why it matters: Most blockchains are either powerful but slow, or fast but expensive. Solana is fast, affordable, and energy-efficie‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Story of the Black Tourmaline and the Hidden Power Within Your Code ‚Äî Why Zyn Is Already Changing the Rules
entry.summary: Zyn is no different. It‚Äôs not just a build system ‚Äî it‚Äôs a source of unseen energy for your code, a silent catalyst empowering developers to create with flow and precision. Maybe you‚Äôve heard of Zyn. Maybe you‚Äôve even used it. But what‚Äôs happening now is just the surface. Like the tourmaline holding mysteries beneath its surface, Zyn holds potential that reveals itself only when you‚Äôre truly ready to tap into it. The story is unfolding ‚Äî quietly, powerfully ‚Äî and it‚Äôs already rewriting the rules of how we build. You‚Äôre part of this story. Keep watching. The real power is yet to come.

entry.title: Connecting Express to MongoDB with Mongoose, .env, and .gitignore
entry.summary:
As you build more powerful Express apps, connecting to a database becomes essential. In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through how to: Connect an Express app to MongoDB using Mongoose
Secure your credentials using .env
Prevent sensitive files from being tracked with .gitignore
Let‚Äôs get started. In your project directory, install: npm install mongoose dotenv
mongoose: ODM (Object Data Modeling) library for MongoDB dotenv: Loads environment variables from .env files .env File
In the root of your project, create a .env file: touch .env
Add your MongoDB connection string: MONGO_URI=mongodb+srv://<username>:<password>@cluster.mongodb.net/myDatabase PORT=5000
Never share this file publicly. .gitignore
To ensure .env and other sensitive files aren‚Äôt committed to Git, create a .gitignore file:‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Everyday Life
entry.summary: Artificial Intelligence AI is no longer a concept of the distant future‚Äîit is now deeply embedded firmly fixed or integrated in nearly every aspect of our daily lives. From smartphones that recognize our faces and voices to personalized content recommendations on social media, AI is transforming how we live, work, learn, and connect with others (Russell & Norvig, 2021). While some of its applications are subtle, others are highly visible and disruptive, offering both convenience and raising important ethical and economic questions. One of the most remarkable worthy of attention; extraordinary developments in AI is in the field of healthcare. Machine learning algorithms can now diagnose identify a disease or problem diseases such as skin cancer, diabetic retinopathy, and even early signs of‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Template Method + Strategy Saved My Payment System (and My Sanity)
Applying API Testing Frameworks: Real-World Examples Using Postman
entry.summary: In the API-driven world of modern software, backend services are only as reliable as the tests we write for them. Whether you‚Äôre building a microservice or a full RESTful API, API testing is essential to validate your endpoints, responses, and business logic. In this article, I‚Äôll walk you through how to use Postman‚Äîone of the most popular API testing frameworks‚Äîto create real-world API tests with practical examples and code. üîπWhy Use a Framework Like Postman? Postman allows developers and QA engineers to: Create and send HTTP requests to an API Write automated test scripts in JavaScript Organize requests into collections Use environments and variables to test across stages (dev, staging, production) It combines ease of use with powerful features for testing REST, GraphQL, and SOAP APIs. ‚Ä¶
